SCTR 持股多, 要有高DISCIPLINE KEEP住換股先得. 同埋一定要個個星期買. 另外COMMISSION 費用都好高
STOPLOSS 一定要SET得好 , 因為入面好多股都高VOL, 一唔SET STOP 就-30%見

最後就係要HOLD個PORTFOLIO耐先有錢返, 因為要等D股爆發

P&L 就同SPY 差唔多.... 可能因為我有好多位有人為出錯....

利伸: 跟足STCR玩左差唔多半年

通常都要等翻幾個星期 業績期到 先會有大波動

係。因為sctr個concept 係高追再高追。買入d爆升股 搏佢再爆升

玩落回報同spy相近但功夫又多 當然唔排除玩耐d可以跑贏指數
同埋呢個system只可以用係極牛市。橫行 同熊都冇運行。

始終係高追買大量領先股。個市跌落黎呢批股會跌得最甘
例子： 3月 sctr持有d金融股 6月d科技股 都係大插 但其實個市都唔係回左好多
所以而家都諗緊好唔好轉楂指數  再人手揀幾隻玩

所以而家都諗緊好唔好轉楂指數 再人手揀幾隻玩

不過vti買賣方便d

所以而家都諗緊好唔好轉楂指數 再人手揀幾隻玩

中國要求國有大行對萬達的海外項目停貸

中國銀行業監管機構6月20日通知幾大國有銀行稱，萬達集團的六項海外並購交易屬於目

前中國對外投資嚴格管控的領域，要求這些銀行暫停向其海外項目發放貸款。


評論

中國監管機構要求國內大型銀行暫停向萬達集團股份有限公司(Dalian Wanda Group Co.)
的海外項目發放貸款。萬達是億萬富翁王健林麾下的地產和娛樂巨頭。

《華爾街日報》(The Wall Street Journal)見到的與會銀行的文件顯示，6月20日，中國
銀行業監管機構與大型國有銀行管理人士召開會議，通知銀行稱，萬達的六項海外並購交
易屬於目前中國對外投資嚴格管控的領域。這其中包括萬達集團收購好萊塢制片公司傳奇
娛樂(Legendary Entertainment)的交易。

一位知情人士說，這份文件可能涉及萬達五年來在美國和歐洲進行的交易。

這些交易的投資對象包括美國院線連鎖公司AMC娛樂控股公司(AMC Entertainment
Holding Inc., AMC)、Carmike Cinemas (CKEC)、英國游艇生產商Sunseeker
International、傳奇娛樂、歐洲劇院運營商Odeon & UCI Cinemas Group和Nordic
Cinema Group。

其中四項交易在2012-2016年完成，另外兩項尚未完成的交易——通過萬達美國子公司AMC
娛樂控股公司收購Odeon和Nordic——似乎不在中國監管規定的管轄範圍內。

中國國務院去年11月出台了限制中國企業對外投資的規定，試圖緩解資本外流給人民幣帶
來的巨大壓力。按照規定，中國不鼓勵國內企業投資海外房地產和娛樂資產。

雖然已有四項交易完成，但最新的監管行動似乎將阻止萬達從國內銀行獲得與這四項收購
有關的新貸款。這一舉措也給尚未完成的兩項交易的融資蒙上了陰影。

此外，中國政府也阻止萬達集團從境內對其海外項目注資。 萬達還被禁止將這些海外資
產注入其國內上市公司。

這份文件似乎解釋了為何萬達在上周意外決定以92.8億美元價格將大部分主題樂園和酒店
業務賣給房地產開發商融創中國控股(Sunac China Holdings Ltd., 1918.HK)。

監管備案文件顯示，萬達將獲取43.5億美元的3年期銀行貸款，然後將這筆資金借給融創
中國。根據融創中國的備案文件，該公司將用這筆借來的錢支付給萬達，獲得萬達主題樂
園業務的所有權。

通過出售自己珍視的酒店和主題樂園資產，萬達將減輕沉重的債務負擔；該公司的債務水
平已經引起中國銀監會的關注。上個月，銀監會要求各銀行清查大舉進行海外並購交易公
司的貸款情況，其中就包括萬達。

萬達集團主席王健林表示，該公司將利用資產出售所得償還大連萬達商業地產股份有限公
司(Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co., 簡稱：萬達地產)的負債。萬達地產正尋
求在中國上市，但尚未獲批。

聽落有道理

ALL home prices are affected at the margin by those willing and able to buy and those that have “For Sale” signs in their front yard. Therefore, if the average American family living on $55,000 a year sees their monthly mortgage payment rise by 50% it is a VERY big issue.

Assume an average American family of four (Ward, June, Wally and The Beaver) are looking for the traditional home with the white picket fence. Since they are the average American family their median family income is approximately $55,000. After taxes, expenses, etc. they realize they can afford roughly a $600 monthly mortgage payment. They contact their realtor and begin shopping for their slice of the “American Dream.”


At a 4% interest rate, they can afford to purchase a $125,000 home. However, as rates rise that purchasing power quickly diminishes. At 5% they are looking for $111,000 home. As rates rise to 6% it is a $100,000 property and at 7%, just back to 2006 levels mind you, their $600 monthly payment will only purchase a $90,000 shack. See what I mean about interest rates?

This also explains WHY America has become a nation of renters as affordability for many is no longer an option.


Since home prices, on the whole, are affected by those actively willing to sell – a rise of interest rates would lead to declines in home prices across the board as sellers reduce prices to find buyers. Since there are only a limited number of buyers in the pool at any given time, the supply / demand curve is critically affected by the variations in interest rates. This is particularly the problem when the average American is more heavily leveraged than at any point in history.


[url]People Buy Payments (Or Why Rates Can't Rise) http://news.valubit.com/?p=659780[/url]

https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/bill-gross-warns-rate-hikes-could-tip-us-into-recession-20170721
Bond guru Bill Gross says it might only take a few more rate increases, even at the Federal Reserve’s gradual pace, to throw the economy into a recession, MarketWatch reports.

The Janus Henderson (formerly Janus Capital) fund manager warns that the resulting economic slowdown could spark a market meltdown.

“Today’s highly levered domestic and global economies which have ‘feasted’ on the easy monetary policies of recent years can likely not stand anywhere close to the flat yield curves witnessed in prior decades,” Gross wrote in his most recently monthly missive to investors. “Central bankers and indeed investors should view additional tightening and ‘normalising’ of short-term rates with caution,” he said. Read the entire market musing, entitled Curveball, here.

The Fed has raised benchmark interest rates four times since its first rate increase in nearly a decade back in December 2015.

READ Nobody told the euro that Mario Draghi was dovish

Gross’ latest views echo earlier admonishments and are similar to concerns that have been raised by other market participants, some of whom have suggested that the Fed should slow its pace of rate hikes amid signs of muted inflation. A Bank of America Merrill Lynch global fund managers’ survey indicated that the second-most concerning “tail risk” remained a central bank policy misstep.

This has manifested itself in a so-called flattening of the yield curve, which is a plot of Treasury yields from shortest to longest. Yield flattening, or an inversion — an anomaly where long-term yields fall below short-term yields — has tended to presage economic weakness, and been an eerily accurate predictor of a recession.

Part of Gross’ logic is that a gradual pace of rate hikes could still have a meaningful impact on the cost of borrowing for corporations and individuals, with interest rates still lingering around historic lows. For example, if a rate increase of a quarter percentage point induced a similar 25-basis-point increase in three-month Treasury bills, which tends to move in lockstep with the Fed-funds rate, it would only take around an 85-basis-point rate increase to double short-term rates.

“The same increase prior to the 1991, 2000 and 2007-2009 recessions would have produced only a 10-20% rise in short rates,” said Gross.

READ Why Mario Draghi can’t back down from ECB taper hints

The bond guru also says low interest rates have kept alive so-called zombie corporations, saddled with excessive debt, which have distorted the typical Darwinism on Wall Street that would see efficient firms replace unprofitable ones. Non-financial corporate debt stands at more than 70% of gross domestic product, close to levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis, according to the Federal Reserve Board. And with more than $1tn of floating-rate student loans weighing on household finances, a hike to borrowing costs could wreak irrevocable damage to consumption spending.

“Commonsensically, a more highly levered economy is more growth sensitive to using short-term interest rates and a flat yield curve,” said Gross.

In the end, he lays the blame at the feet of central bankers. Likening them to a compulsive drinker, who promises “sobriety is around the corner”. Gross said the exit from out of extraordinary monetary policy could get ugly, despite policy makers’ confidence that they can end an age of extraordinary stimulus without consequence.

Known as a fierce critic of quantitative easing, Gross once described the Fed’s bond-buying programme as a Ponzi scheme in previous commentary.

7.市場走勢？
市場走勢：向上，受壓，調整
向上：可以買貨！
受壓：注意個股有沒進入止損位／止賺位，停止買進股票
調整：沽出持股獲利. 如果唔想沽出股票獲利，可以用期權進行對沖

最簡單既法則：周線圖決定上升走勢／下跌走勢＝指數收市價跌穿30周線，日線圖指數收市價跌穿200日線，就假設已經進入下跌走勢，就要沽貨！e個既法則都有缺點！～通常個市已經跌左好多，係跌勢既三分之一


市場走勢最難去決定，所以大家用可以用自己既方法去判定
